questions.question: Assuming you count in calendar days, how many days elapsed between the day when the Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council hosted the final day of the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship at Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center and the deadline day by which editor Ralen Ko, during the planning meeting for a three-part 10–12 page series, asked Lina Veress to submit her first draft?

distractors.explanation: This would be the elapsed time if someone mistakenly measured from the final day on 2025-03-22 to the council’s permission date on 2025-06-18 (when statistics and photos were approved) instead of to the requested draft deadline of 2025-06-20. The question, however, asks specifically about the deadline day in the planning meeting, so 88 days is too short.

This matches the span from the final day on 2025-03-22 to the mid-year issue’s release on 2025-06-30, which might be confused with the “mid-year print deadline.” However, Ralen Ko asked for the draft by 2025-06-20, not the publication date, so 100 days does not answer the question as stated.

Using the correct dates (2025-03-22 to 2025-06-20) but counting both the starting and ending dates inclusively gives 91 calendar dates touched. The question, however, asks for days elapsed between those days (a difference in dates), which is 90, so 91 overcounts by one.

This can result from a small month-length error—for example, still starting on 2025-03-22 and ending on 2025-06-20, but wrongly assuming May has only 30 days. That gives 9 (March) + 30 (April) + 30 (May) + 20 (June) = 89. Since May actually has 31 days, this total is one day short and therefore incorrect.

Because the span from late March to late June is “about three months,” a rough or mistaken breakdown of the month lengths (for example, accidentally double-counting one of the 31-day months) can lead to 92 days as a plausible near-miss. Using the actual dates and correct month lengths, however, the elapsed time is 90 days, not 92.

Also, for calculation, treat the “shortly after” wording used to describe the sending time of head coach Marlen Tiravo’s email with the subject line “Equipment grant update – Grendale U17” to Neris Dalvo as indicating exactly the clock time mentioned in the outline for that email. Under these assumptions, how much time elapsed between the publication of that brief comment and the sending of that email?

distractors.explanation: This wrongly assumes the brief comment by Neris Dalvo became publicly available around midday on 2025-06-30 (for example, 12:00), instead of at the very start of the publication day as specified in the question. From 12:00 on 2025-06-30 to 17:15 on 2025-07-03 would be 3 days 5 hours 15 minutes, not the correct 3 days 17 hours 15 minutes.

This option effectively rounds the 17:15 sending time of the email down to 17:00, or assumes the publication time was 00:15 instead of 00:00 on 2025-06-30. Under the given assumptions (start of day publication and an email at exactly 17:15), the elapsed time must include the extra 15 minutes, so 3 days 17 hours is slightly too short.

This reflects a one-day counting error, as if the feature comment had only become publicly available at the start of 2025-07-01 instead of 2025-06-30. From 2025-07-01 00:00 to 2025-07-03 17:15 would indeed be 2 days 17 hours 15 minutes, but the outline clearly dates the brief comment to 2025-06-30.

This assumes the brief comment was effectively available a full day earlier, on 2025-06-29, rather than on 2025-06-30. Counting from 00:00 on 2025-06-29 to 17:15 on 2025-07-03 would yield 4 days 17 hours 15 minutes, but the outline specifies that the comment was published with the 2025-06-30 issue.

This misreads “shortly after 17:15” as meaning a later effective send time, such as 17:30, instead of treating it as exactly 17:15 as the question instructs. From 00:00 on 2025-06-30 to 17:30 on 2025-07-03 would be 3 days 17 hours 30 minutes, which is 15 minutes longer than the correct elapsed time.

questions.question: Assuming you count only whole calendar days and ignore the exact times of day, how many days passed between the release of the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly mid-year print issue that included Lina Veress’s article titled “Pressing in Pairs” and the short pre-warm-up meeting in which Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 coach Harven Soll told his players they would apply ideas from that article in their friendly against Varlen Crest Futsal Club Under-17?

distractors.explanation: This is an off-by-one miscount between 2025-06-30 and 2025-07-12, or it could come from informally shifting the “real” use of the material to the start of July (when the new fitness coach joined) instead of the actual release date on 2025-06-30. However, counting calendar days from 2025-06-30 to 2025-07-12 gives 12, not 11.

This matches an inclusive counting mistake (counting both 2025-06-30 and 2025-07-12 as full days passed) rather than the number of days between them. The question asks how many days passed between those dates, which is a 12-day span, not 13.

This could come from confusing the 2025-07-12 meeting with the 2025-07-03 low-pressure training session and then counting from the magazine release on 2025-06-30 to 2025-07-03. That gap is three days, but the meeting in which Harven Soll told his players they would apply “Pressing in Pairs” took place on 2025-07-12, so 3 days is not the correct interval.

This uses 2025-06-18, when the council granted permission to reproduce statistics and photographs, as the starting date instead of the actual release date of the mid-year issue on 2025-06-30. From 2025-06-18 to 2025-07-12 is 24 days, but the question is anchored to the release of the print issue, not the earlier permission email.

This could come from mixing up the magazine’s 2025-06-30 release with the 2025-07-02 delivery date of the new equipment order, a pair of dates mentioned close together in the outline. The interval from 2025-06-30 to 2025-07-02 is two days, but the question asks about the time until the 2025-07-12 pre-warm-up meeting, so 2 days is incorrect.

questions.question:
Assume that Lina Veress submitted her first draft of the three-part feature at exactly the first moment of the calendar day by which her editor, during the planning meeting at the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly office, had asked her to have that draft ready. Also assume that the pre-season futsal friendly hosted by Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 against Varlen Crest Futsal Club Under-17 at Meadowlane’s indoor court consisted of exactly two back-to-back 20-minute halves with no halftime interval or added time, so that it ended precisely 40 minutes after its stated kick-off time. 

Under these assumptions, how much time elapsed between Lina’s hypothetical submission moment and the final whistle of that Meadowlane vs. Varlen Crest friendly?

distractors.explanation: This assumes Lina submitted at the very end of the deadline day (23:59 on 2025-06-20) instead of at its first moment (00:00). Counting from 2025-06-20 23:59 to 2025-07-12 16:50 yields 21 days 16 hours 49 minutes, not the correct longer interval from the start of 2025-06-20.

This incorrectly uses 2025-06-18—the date when permission was granted for using statistics and photos—as if it were the draft deadline, then measures from 2025-06-18 00:00 to the friendly’s final whistle at 2025-07-12 16:50. That span is 24 days 16 hours 50 minutes, but the question bases the timing on the “by 2025-06-20” draft date.

This treats the vague “early June” commissioning of the feature as if it happened at the very start of the month (e.g., 2025-06-01 00:00) and then measures to 2025-07-12 16:50, giving 41 days 16 hours 50 minutes. The calculation should instead start from the specified draft deadline date, 2025-06-20.

This mistakenly uses the mid-year print issue’s release date, 2025-06-30, as the starting point—measuring from 2025-06-30 00:00 to 2025-07-12 16:50. That gives 12 days 16 hours 50 minutes, but the problem clearly anchors the timing to the draft deadline day (2025-06-20), not the publication date.

This uses the correct draft deadline (start of 2025-06-20) but incorrectly takes 16:10—the kick-off time—as the end of the match, ignoring the stated assumption that the game lasted exactly 40 minutes. From 2025-06-20 00:00 to 2025-07-12 16:10 is 22 days 16 hours 10 minutes, slightly shorter than the correct interval to the 16:50 final whistle.

questions.question: In the pre-season friendly between Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 and Varlen Crest Futsal Club Under-17, focus only on the second half. One goal for Varlen came when a Meadowlane defender’s misplaced square pass near the attacking third was intercepted and turned into a counterattack that produced the opening goal of the half. Later in the same half, wide player Talen Priev scored for Meadowlane after stepping into a lateral pass near the center circle during a coordinated press. If you treat the described “roughly” and “around” timings as exact (i.e., the first of these goals happened exactly when stated after the restart, and Talen Priev’s goal happened exactly in the stated minute of the half), how many minutes of second-half play elapsed between these two goals?

distractors.explanation: This would be the gap if someone misremembered Talen Priev’s goal as coming in the 6th minute instead of “around the ninth minute,” subtracting 3 (for Varlen’s goal) from that mistaken 6. The text, however, says Varlen’s goal was roughly 3 minutes after the restart and Talen’s was around the 9th minute of the half, giving a 6‑minute gap, not 3.

This could come from treating “around the ninth minute” as roughly the 8th minute and subtracting Varlen’s goal at the 3rd minute (8 − 3 = 5). But the problem states we must treat the “roughly” and “around” timings as exact, so the correct calculation is 9 − 3 = 6 minutes, not 5.

A reader might mistakenly place Varlen’s goal “roughly three minutes after the restart” closer to the 2nd minute, then subtract from Talen Priev’s 9th‑minute goal (9 − 2 = 7). However, treating the times exactly as given—3rd minute and 9th minute—yields a 6‑minute interval, not 7.

This answer might arise if someone confuses the question and simply uses the stated “around the ninth minute” for Talen Priev’s goal as the interval itself, ignoring when Varlen’s earlier goal occurred. The outline clearly puts Varlen’s goal roughly 3 minutes after the restart and Talen’s around the 9th minute, so the elapsed time between them is 6 minutes, not 9.

A careless approach might add the two stated times—3 minutes after the restart and the 9th minute (3 + 9 = 12)—instead of finding the difference. The question asks how many minutes of second‑half play elapsed between the goals, so the correct operation is subtraction (9 − 3), giving 6 minutes, not 12.

Based on this, by how many minutes did their hall booking at Northline Community Sports Hall exceed the planned game time of the rematch?

distractors.explanation: This assumes the earlier friendly lasted 50 minutes (two 20-minute halves plus an invented 10‑minute halftime) and then subtracts that from the 90‑minute booking window: 90 − 50 = 40. The outline never specifies any halftime duration; using only the given “two 20‑minute halves,” the match length is 40 minutes, so the excess booking time is 50, not 40.

This could come from wrongly assuming the earlier match lasted just 30 minutes (for example, misreading “two 20‑minute halves” as two 15‑minute halves) and then doing 90 − 30 = 60. However, the outline clearly states two 20‑minute halves, so the game time is 40 minutes, making the surplus booking time 50 minutes.

A reader might mistakenly think only one 20‑minute half was planned for the earlier friendly, or confuse the 90‑minute booking with a shorter slot (e.g., 70 minutes, then 70 − 40 = 30). The text explicitly gives a 90‑minute window at Northline and “two 20‑minute halves” for the earlier game, so the correct difference is 90 − 40 = 50 minutes, not 30.

This would follow from an incorrect assumption that the rematch itself was only 20 minutes long (for example, misreading “two 20‑minute halves” as a single 20‑minute period) and then subtracting that from the 90‑minute slot: 90 − 20 = 70. The outline clearly specifies two 20‑minute halves for the earlier friendly, so the rematch would also be 40 minutes, leaving 50 extra minutes in the booking, not 70.

This number may be confused with the separate twelve‑minute mixed‑squad training game played on the reduced court at Northline, but that 12‑minute segment was not the planned full-length rematch. The actual planned match duration is tied to the earlier friendly’s two 20‑minute halves (40 minutes), inside a 90‑minute booking window, so the booking exceeds game time by 50 minutes, not 12.

  - N9-S12 uniquely establishes the advisory event (what was advised, and that it occurred in that consultation).
  - N9-S13 uniquely establishes that a reassessment date “two weeks ahead” of that consultation was circled as the end point.
- Without N9-S12, the start event (“the time he instructed Riven Hall to avoid those specific activities”) is not defined.

[Answer derivation]:
- Start: consultation and advice at Meadowlane Crossway Clinic = 2025-08-23.
- End: reassessment date circled on discharge sheet = “two weeks ahead” of 2025-08-23.
- Two weeks = 14 days.
- 2025-08-23 + 14 days = 2025-09-06.
- Time span between advice and provisional reassessment date = 14 days.</scratchpad>

previous_version.question: Assuming that orthopedic physician doctor Sevin Karlo circled the provisional reassessment date on Riven Hall’s discharge sheet during the same Meadowlane Crossway Clinic consultation in which he instructed him to avoid goalkeeping dives, heavy wrist loading, and formal futsal goalkeeping, how many days lay between the moment of that instruction and the provisional date chosen to reassess full goalkeeping activities?
previous_version.additional_sentence_explanation: No additional sentences beyond N9-S12 and N9-S13 are required. N9-S12 uniquely defines the consultation in which the specific avoidance instructions were given, and N9-S13 uniquely states that a date exactly two weeks ahead of that same consultation was circled as the provisional reassessment point; together they are sufficient and both are necessary to compute the duration.

event_type.category: Major Tournament Results and Championship Outcomes

events.summary: A youth futsal team representing a suburban academy claimed the under-17 regional championship, winning all five of its matches and conceding only two goals in the tournament.

outline.sentence: The {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} hosted the final day of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} at {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1} on 2025-03-22.

The final day program at {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1} began at 09:00 with warm-up sessions and team check-ins, with the main court stands gradually filling to an estimated crowd of around 450 spectators by the time of the afternoon final.

{Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1} featured two regulation futsal courts with a blue synthetic surface and electronic scoreboards, and the {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} used the central court exclusively for the under-17 semifinal and final fixtures.

{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} entered the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} as the qualifying representative team of the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} of {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2}.

{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} had secured the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} berth two weeks earlier by finishing top of the zone’s qualifying league on goal difference after a six-match campaign.

The squad of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} registered for the tournament consisted of 12 players aged between 15 and 17 years, coached and supported by a staff group of four including a fitness coach and a team physiotherapist.
{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} won all three group-stage matches of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} to finish first in {Group A|MISCELLANEOUS-2}.

In {Group A|MISCELLANEOUS-2}, {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} recorded a 3–0 win over {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4}, a 2–1 victory against {Selvarin East Secondary Under-17|ORGANIZATION-5}, and a 1–0 result over {Orvath Ridge Collegiate Under-17|ORGANIZATION-6}.

The group-stage fixtures for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} were played over three consecutive evenings at {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1}, with the team mathematically securing a semifinal place after just the second match.
{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} conceded only one goal during the three group-stage matches of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

The lone group-stage goal against {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} was scored from a 6-meter penalty by forward {Laren Vos|PERSON-1} of {Selvarin East Secondary Under-17|ORGANIZATION-5} late in the first half of their second group match.

Goalkeeper {Ren Talvek|PERSON-2} of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} was named player of the match in two of the three group fixtures after making several close-range saves to preserve narrow leads.

{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} defeated {Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17|ORGANIZATION-7} by 2–1 in the semifinal of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

In the semifinal, winger {Daren Mol|PERSON-3} of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} opened the scoring in the 7th minute, and pivot {Jorin Kale|PERSON-4} netted the decisive second goal midway through the second half after a set-play corner routine.

The semifinal between {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} and {Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17|ORGANIZATION-7} was officiated by referee {Elvin Sarro|PERSON-5} and two assistant referees, with the match played at a high tempo and several tactical time-outs called by both benches.

The 2–1 semifinal victory over {Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17|ORGANIZATION-7} gave {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} a second goal conceded in the entire {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

The goal conceded in the semifinal came from a deflected long-range shot early in the second half, briefly leveling the score at 1–1 before {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} restored the lead.

Despite the setback, the defensive unit of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} responded by limiting {Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17|ORGANIZATION-7} to speculative efforts from distance in the final minutes.

{Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} won the final of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} with a 3–0 victory over {Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17|ORGANIZATION-8} at {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1}.

The final kicked off at 16:30 on the main court, with {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} captain and playmaker {Mikel Ardan|PERSON-6} scoring twice and flank player {Sera Noll|PERSON-7} adding a third goal on a fast break in the closing stages.

{Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17|ORGANIZATION-8} struggled to break down the compact 2–2 defensive shape employed by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}, managing only a handful of shots on target over the two 20-minute halves.

With five wins from five matches, {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} secured the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} title while conceding only two goals in the tournament.

Across the five matches of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}, {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} scored a total of 11 goals, finishing with the best goal difference of any team in the competition.

Several school coaches and spectators at {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1} remarked that the consistency shown by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} across all phases of play set a benchmark for future editions of the under-17 event.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} credited the championship success of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} to defensive discipline and consistent training in a post-final interview with the {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} media team.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8}, who has led youth teams at {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} for five seasons, highlighted that the under-17 squad had trained four evenings per week since January with a special focus on pressing and transition drills.

During the interview conducted courtside by council media officer {Lina Veress|PERSON-9}, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} stated that the players had “treated every session as if it were a final,” emphasizing their commitment and punctuality throughout the preparation period.

The {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} awarded {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} a development grant for new training equipment in recognition of the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} victory by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}.

The development grant from the {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} was announced as a package valued at approximately 3,000 {selvars|MISCELLANEOUS-1}, earmarked for purchasing new futsal balls, portable goals, and agility training gear for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}.

Representatives of the {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} handed the official grant confirmation letter to head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} at the edge of the main court, with the players of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} gathered around in team tracksuits.

continuation.summary: On 2025-06-30, sports communications officer Lina Veress released an in-depth print feature series in a regional youth sports magazine dissecting Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s title run at the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship, which local coaches cited as a practical reference even though no separate school case-study materials were produced.

events.summary: On 2025-06-30, sports communications officer Lina Veress released an in-depth print feature series in a regional youth sports magazine dissecting Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s title run at the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship, which local coaches cited as a practical reference even though no separate school case-study materials were produced.

outline.sentence: In early June 2025, editor {Ralen Ko|PERSON-10} of the regional magazine {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} commissioned sports communications officer {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} to write a print feature series on the title run of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} at the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

During a planning meeting at the modest {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} office near the eastern tram loop in {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2}, editor {Ralen Ko|PERSON-10} outlined a three-part, 10–12 page series and asked {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} to submit a first draft by 2025-06-20 to meet the mid-year print deadline.

Editor {Ralen Ko|PERSON-10} specifically cited the composed courtside interview that {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} had conducted with head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} after the final as a key reason for assigning the feature, believing that {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} could balance tactical detail with human-interest storytelling for a youth audience.

On 2025-06-18, {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} granted {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} permission to reproduce selected statistics and photographs from the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} in the feature series authored by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9}.

The permission was confirmed in a two-page email agreement signed off by {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} chairperson {Doran Helv|PERSON-11}, stipulating that all images be credit-lined to the council archive and used only in connection with non-elite youth futsal education.

Along with the written approval, {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} provided {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} with a folder of 24 high-resolution action photographs and the official match-statistics spreadsheets for all five fixtures played by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}.

In preparation for the {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} feature series, {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} conducted extended interviews with head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} focusing on training structure, team culture, and the weeks leading up to the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

The interviews consisted of two evening video calls and one in-person conversation at the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} office, each lasting around 70 to 90 minutes, with head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} bringing along a binder of weekly training schedules from January to March 2025.

During these discussions, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} described specific routines such as Monday small-sided pressing games and Thursday match-simulation blocks, and emphasized to {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} how player-led feedback circles on Fridays had helped shape the squad’s sense of collective responsibility.

{Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} staff used match footage from {Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center|BUILDING-1} to create tactical diagrams and sequence illustrations that visually supported the written analysis by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} of the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} performances.

The magazine’s two-person analysis team replayed key passages from the semifinal and final on a large screen in their editing room, manually logging pressing triggers, passing lanes, and player rotations that could be translated into simplified diagrams for young readers.

Graphic designer {Hele Narm|PERSON-12} transformed these notes into four full-page diagrams and several smaller in-text sequences, using colored arrows and numbered frames to show how {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} shifted from a compact 2–2 block into coordinated counter-attacks.

On the morning of 2025-06-30, {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} released its mid-year print issue featuring a multi-part analytical series by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} on the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} campaign at the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1}.

The issue, Volume 13 Number 2, had a print run of approximately 2,500 copies and was distributed to secondary schools, community sports halls, and neighborhood kiosks across {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2} and the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} at a cover price of 8 {selvars|MISCELLANEOUS-1}.

The front cover of the mid-year issue featured a full-width photograph of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} captain {Mikel Ardan|PERSON-6} lifting the championship trophy, with a headline banner reading “How Grendale Built a Champion Team.”

Within the 2025-06-30 issue of {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9}, an article titled “{Pressing in Pairs|ART-1}” by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} detailed a recurring defensive pattern used by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} during the {Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship|EVENT-1} and translated it into step-by-step drills for youth coaches.

The “{Pressing in Pairs|ART-1}” piece filled four magazine pages and broke the concept into three progressive training blocks, each specifying recommended pitch dimensions, work-to-rest ratios, and suggested adaptations for under-13, under-15, and under-17 age groups.

A highlighted sidebar within the article quoted head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} explaining how a simple verbal cue of “step and cover” helped {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} players coordinate their movements when initiating the paired press in competitive matches.

On the afternoon of 2025-06-30, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} held a classroom-style review session at the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} training facility where {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} distributed copies of the {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} feature series by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} to the players of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}.

The review session took place in a small upstairs meeting room overlooking the indoor training court, with around a dozen players seated at desks while head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} used a whiteboard and a projector to walk through key diagrams from the magazine.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} asked each player of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} to highlight at least one paragraph that reflected their own habits, leading to a brief discussion in which several players expressed surprise at seeing their off-the-ball work described in print.

By the evening of 2025-06-30, several school futsal coaches in {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2}, including {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13}, reported using the {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} articles by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} as practical reference material for planning upcoming youth training sessions.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} of {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} marked specific drills from “{Pressing in Pairs|ART-1}” with sticky notes in his planning notebook and penciled them into his July pre-season schedule as alternatives to his standard defensive warm-up routines.

Other coaches in {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2} mentioned in informal messages to editor {Ralen Ko|PERSON-10} that they appreciated the clear field diagrams and ready-made session plans, which allowed them to adapt {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} concepts without having to design exercises from scratch.

In a brief comment published alongside the feature series on 2025-06-30, {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} development coordinator {Neris Dalvo|PERSON-14} stated that {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} did not plan to produce separate official school case-study booklets about the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} title run.

The note from development coordinator {Neris Dalvo|PERSON-14} appeared in a shaded “{Council Perspective|ART-2}” box at the bottom of the first feature page, where {Neris Dalvo|PERSON-14} cited limited staff capacity and a preference for issuing broader coaching guidelines rather than detailed profiles of single teams.

In the same comment, development coordinator {Neris Dalvo|PERSON-14} nevertheless thanked {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} for setting “a positive standard for preparation and sportsmanship” and expressed support for independent publications that highlighted constructive youth coaching practices.

Despite the absence of dedicated case-study materials from {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1}, local coaches in the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} and broader {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2} began informally treating the series by {Lina Veress|PERSON-9} in {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} as a de facto reference document for youth futsal training discussions.

During informal planning conversations and email exchanges on 2025-06-30, several coaches referred to specific pages of the {Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly|ORGANIZATION-9} issue—such as the transition-attack diagram on page 11—as shorthand examples when debating how aggressively to press with teenage players.

Some coaches in the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} scanned or photographed selected layouts from the feature series and shared them within small staff groups, using the material as a common visual basis for adjusting their own session content rather than as any kind of official curriculum.

continuation.summary: On 2025-07-03, Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 used the newly purchased futsal balls, portable goals, and agility gear for a low-pressure introductory session focused on individual ball control and movement patterns, with head coach Marlen Tiravo deliberately postponing any pressing or transition drills until the following week.

events.summary: On 2025-07-03, Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 used the newly purchased futsal balls, portable goals, and agility gear for a low-pressure introductory session focused on individual ball control and movement patterns, with head coach Marlen Tiravo deliberately postponing any pressing or transition drills until the following week.

outline.sentence: On 2025-07-03, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} led a 90-minute low-pressure afternoon training session for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} at the indoor court of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3}.

The 90-minute training window for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} on 2025-07-03 ran from 15:30 to 17:00, with the overhead lights switched on despite clear weather outside to keep the indoor court conditions consistent.

A total of 11 players from the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} registered squad attended the 2025-07-03 session, with one player excused in advance due to a minor illness reported to head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} earlier in the day.

Before the start of the 2025-07-03 session, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} and newly appointed fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15} arranged the new futsal balls, portable goals, and agility equipment along one side of the indoor court of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} for use by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}.

The equipment layout prepared by head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} and fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15} on 2025-07-03 included a neat row of twelve white-and-blue size-4 futsal balls, two collapsible 2-by-3-meter portable goals, two flat agility ladders, and eight low yellow mini-hurdles positioned just inside the touchline.

Fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15}, who had formally joined the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} staff at the start of July after previously assisting with younger age groups at the academy, took several minutes to check ball inflation with a handheld pressure gauge before the players stepped onto the court.

The futsal balls, portable goals, and agility equipment used by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} on 2025-07-03 had been purchased earlier in the week by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} with part of the development grant previously awarded by {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1}.

According to staff at {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3}, the order for the new futsal balls, portable goals, and agility equipment had been placed with a {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2} sports supplier on 2025-06-30 and delivered to the {Grendale Suburban Zone|LOCATION-1} facility on the afternoon of 2025-07-02.

Around two-thirds of the 3,000-{selvars|MISCELLANEOUS-1} development grant from {Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council|ORGANIZATION-1} was allocated to the equipment package used on 2025-07-03, with the remaining funds at {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3} earmarked for future replacement items and basic maintenance costs.

At the beginning of the 2025-07-03 session, the players of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} completed a gentle dynamic warm-up of jogging, joint-mobility work, and short accelerations under the supervision of head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8}.

The initial warm-up block for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} on 2025-07-03 lasted roughly 12 minutes and took place in two staggered lines running the length of the court, with exercises such as hip-openers, arm swings, and side shuffles interspersed between light jogs.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} walked slowly along the sideline during the warm-up on 2025-07-03, occasionally stopping a player to adjust posture or stride length and reminding the group that the day’s focus was on “waking the body up, not testing limits.”

Following the warm-up on 2025-07-03, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} organized {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} into small groups for individual ball-control stations that emphasized toe-touches, rolls, and turns using the new futsal balls supplied by {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy|ORGANIZATION-3}.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} divided the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} players into three groups spread across half the court, rotating them every three minutes between stations that focused on fast toe-taps, sole rolls over five-meter lanes, and tight 180-degree turns around cones.

During the ball-control segment on 2025-07-03, captain {Mikel Ardan|PERSON-6} and flank player {Sera Noll|PERSON-7} were asked by head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} to demonstrate a sequence of inside-outside touches at one station before the rest of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} repeated the pattern at a slower tempo.

During the middle phase of the 2025-07-03 practice, fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15} led {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} through low-intensity agility patterns over the new ladders and mini-hurdles to reintroduce movement mechanics without imposing heavy physical load.

The agility phase run by fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15} on 2025-07-03 featured simple in-in-out foot patterns through the ladders, lateral shuffles, and single-step hops over the mini-hurdles, with each repetition kept to 10–12 seconds followed by at least 30 seconds of rest.

Fitness coach {Kelran Dov|PERSON-15} carried a clipboard during the agility work for {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2}, jotting brief notes on knee alignment and upper-body control while offering verbal cues such as “soft landings” and “eyes forward” after each short set.

In the final third of the 2025-07-03 session, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} set up the portable goals so that {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} could perform relaxed finishing exercises with minimal defensive pressure and an emphasis on clean technique.

For the finishing drills on 2025-07-03, the two portable goals were placed about nine meters from the end lines on opposite sides of the court, and {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} players worked in pairs combining a wall pass and a controlled first touch before shooting.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} encouraged the {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} players to alternate between dominant and weaker feet during the finishing segment and frequently stopped sequences to praise composed body shape or a well-placed low shot into the corners.

At a brief pause before the last exercise block on 2025-07-03, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} told the players of {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} that pressing drills and transition games would be deliberately postponed until the following week so that the team could first adjust to the new equipment.

Standing near the center circle with the squad gathered around, head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} explained that he wanted {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} to “learn exactly how these balls move on the floor before we ask you to sprint and press again,” prompting several players to nod in agreement.

Head coach {Marlen Tiravo|PERSON-8} also reminded {Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17|ORGANIZATION-2} during the pause that the concepts from the recent “{Pressing in Pairs|ART-1}” article would still be part of the upcoming training cycle, but that 2025-07-03 was intended as a technical reset rather than an intense tactical session.

outline.sentence: On 2025-08-22, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} began an after-school training session for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} on the indoor court of {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} in the {Meadowlane Quarter|LOCATION-3} of {Selvarin City|LOCATION-2}.

The 2025-08-22 training session for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} started shortly after 16:05, with twelve listed players jogging in from the corridor as coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} ticked their names off on a folded attendance sheet clipped to his clipboard.

Before the warm-up on 2025-08-22, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} used the small court-side whiteboard to write “step and cover,” “lock line,” and “reset block” in large letters, telling the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} players that the session would be a final tune-up before the {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} fixtures.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} organized {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} into a series of small-sided pressing games that applied cues from the article {Pressing in Pairs|ART-1} during the 2025-08-22 training session.

The small-sided pressing games on 2025-08-22 were set up as 4v4 contests plus a neutral support player on half a court, with {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} earning points for turnovers won in the attacking half within five seconds of the initial “step and cover” cue.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} ran each small-sided pressing round for three-minute bursts using the wall-mounted clock as a guide, rotating the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} groups between attack and defense so that every player repeatedly practiced both roles in the paired press.

During one small-sided pressing game on 2025-08-22, goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} made a full-stretch dive to his right to stop a low shot near the edge of the penalty area.

The shot that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} faced on 2025-08-22 came from a {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} teammate cutting in from the left channel, and the ball skimmed off the polished wooden floor toward the far corner before goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} managed to tip it around the makeshift training cone being used as a goalpost.

Several {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} players on the sideline instinctively shouted encouragement as goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} launched himself, with one player calling out “great reach, {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}” just as goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} slid across the court.

As goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} completed the diving save for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} on 2025-08-22, goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} landed awkwardly on his outstretched right wrist and immediately signaled discomfort to coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13}.

After the landing on 2025-08-22, goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} rolled onto his back, pulled off his right glove with his left hand, and grimaced while cradling his wrist against his chest before calling out to coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} that something did not feel right.

Two nearby {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} defenders immediately waved toward the bench for help as goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} remained seated on the floor near the edge of the penalty area rubbing the underside of his right wrist.

Noticing the reaction of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} stopped the small-sided pressing game for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} on 2025-08-22 and suspended all contact drills for the remainder of the session.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} blew his whistle twice in quick succession on 2025-08-22, asked the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} players to jog slowly to the far touchline, and told the group that the rest of the training would be limited to light passing patterns and stretching while goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} was checked.

After moving goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} carefully to a bench along the wall, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} made a brief note in the margin of his session plan indicating the time of the incident and circling the phrase “no contact” to remind himself to adjust upcoming training content.

School nurse {Tera Milvon|PERSON-23} from {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4}’s host school was called to the indoor court on 2025-08-22 and applied an ice pack and supportive bandage to the right wrist of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}.

School nurse {Tera Milvon|PERSON-23} arrived at the indoor court within roughly ten minutes of being called on 2025-08-22, asked goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to rate his pain and to move each finger, and noted mild swelling around the base of the thumb before securing the wrist with a wrap bandage.

While applying the ice pack on 2025-08-22, school nurse {Tera Milvon|PERSON-23} advised goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} not to attempt any more ball work that evening and suggested that an x-ray at a local clinic would be sensible if the pain remained sharp with movement.

After the on-court assessment on 2025-08-22, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} telephoned guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to describe the wrist injury and to recommend that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} be examined at a local clinic the same evening.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} stepped into the quiet corridor outside the changing rooms to call guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} on 2025-08-22, calmly explaining the circumstances of the dive, the school nurse’s initial findings, and emphasizing that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} had been able to walk off the court unaided.

Guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} told coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} during the 2025-08-22 phone call that guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} would pick goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} up within about twenty minutes and drive to a nearby medical center, promising to update coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} once a doctor had seen the injury.

Concerned about early-season availability after the 2025-08-22 incident, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} contacted student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} later that day to invite {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} to fast-track into {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} as a backup option.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} reached student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} by phone early on the evening of 2025-08-22, explaining that student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25}’s strong performances in recent school physical education futsal blocks had marked student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} as the most ready-made cover option.

Student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} expressed surprise but agreed during the 2025-08-22 conversation to attend the next {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} training session, asking coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} for details on kit colors, arrival times, and any extra goalkeeper drills to expect.

That night on 2025-08-22, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} updated the paper planning notebook for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} by penciling goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} as a possible starter for initial fixtures in the {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} if goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} remained unavailable.

Sitting at his kitchen table in the {Meadowlane Quarter|LOCATION-3} on 2025-08-22, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} drew a small asterisk beside the goalkeeper line on the first two {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} match pages, writing “{Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} / adjust build-out patterns” in the margin.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} also noted in the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} planning notebook on 2025-08-22 that extra ten-minute goalkeeper-specific sequences would be added to upcoming sessions to help goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} adapt quickly to the team’s pressing and distribution cues.

Following the 2025-08-22 training session, several players from {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} posted short messages in the team’s private {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group wishing goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} a quick recovery from the right wrist injury.

Messages in the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group on 2025-08-22 included simple notes such as “rest that wrist, we need you back soon” and “thanks for still helping organize the press today,” with one {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} defender attaching a photo from an earlier match where goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} was celebrating a save.

Later that evening on 2025-08-22, goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} replied in the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} was on the way to a clinic with guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} for checks and thanked the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} teammates for the supportive messages.

continuation.summary: On 2025-08-23, medical checks confirm Meadowlane goalkeeper Riven Hall has no serious structural wrist damage but should avoid goalkeeping for at least two weeks, so coach Harven Soll plans for Jasmin Korrel to start in goal while temporarily involving Hall as a limited-minutes outfield option in early league matches.

outline.sentence: On the morning of 2025-08-23, guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} drove goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} for a scheduled medical assessment of the right wrist injury from the previous {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} training session.

Guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} and goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} left the {Meadowlane Quarter|LOCATION-3} shortly after 09:00 under overcast skies, with goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} wearing a {Meadowlane School|ORGANIZATION-13} hoodie and the original wrap bandage applied by school nurse {Tera Milvon|PERSON-23} still in place on the right wrist.

During the short drive to {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12}, goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} scrolled through earlier messages in the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group on his phone while guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} kept a printed copy of the school’s injury insurance information on the passenger seat.

At {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} on 2025-08-23, orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} carried out a detailed physical examination of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s right wrist, checking range of motion, tenderness, and stability.

Orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26}, a soft‑spoken sports-injury specialist in his early forties, began the consultation by asking goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to describe the exact training action and landing that had caused the pain on 2025-08-22.

During the examination, orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} compared both of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s wrists side by side, palpated along the thumb side of the joint, and asked goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to rate his discomfort on a ten-point pain scale when bending or twisting the joint.

The imaging department at {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} performed a series of right-wrist x-ray scans for goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} on 2025-08-23 at the request of doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26}.

In the imaging room, a radiographer positioned goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s right arm on a flat x‑ray plate with a foam wedge for support, placed a lead apron across goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s torso, and took three standard views while asking goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to hold perfectly still for a few seconds each time.

Guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} watched the procedure through the protective glass panel as the radiographer confirmed that the images would be sent electronically to orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} within about fifteen minutes.

Later on 2025-08-23, doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} informed goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} and guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} at {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} that the wrist x-ray showed no fractures or major ligament tears and that the injury was a moderate sprain.

In the consultation room, orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} pulled the x‑ray images up on a wall-mounted screen, tracing the outline of the carpal bones with a pen while explaining to goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} and guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} that the joint spaces and alignment looked normal.

Orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} described the diagnosis as a moderate sprain of the supporting ligaments around the wrist joint with an expected improvement over roughly 10 to 14 days if goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} followed the rest advice, prompting a visible look of relief mixed with frustration on goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s face.

Doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} advised goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} on 2025-08-23 at {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} to avoid goalkeeping dives, heavy wrist loading, and formal futsal goalkeeping for at least two weeks while permitting light jogging and gentle passing after several days if pain allowed.

Orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} wrote the key restrictions and time frames on a printed discharge sheet, circling a date two weeks ahead as a provisional point to reassess full goalkeeping activities for goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}.

Orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26} recommended that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} use ice on the wrist for 10 to 15 minutes three times a day over the next two days and then add gentle, pain‑free wrist circles and finger exercises to prevent stiffness.

Shortly after leaving {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} on 2025-08-23, guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} telephoned coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} to report doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26}’s diagnosis for goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} and to outline the two-week restriction from goalkeeping activity.

Guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} made the call from the clinic car park while goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} sat beside guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} in the front seat, and guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} read out phrases from the discharge notes such as “no fracture seen” and “avoid diving for 14 days” to coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13}.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} took the call in the small physical education office at {Meadowlane School|ORGANIZATION-13}, balancing the phone between shoulder and ear while jotting “{Riven Hall|PERSON-16} – 2 weeks no GK (sprain)” in the margin of the afternoon training plan.

Following the call with guardian {Mara Hall|PERSON-24} on 2025-08-23, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} updated the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} paper planning notebook to list student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} as the starting goalkeeper for the first fixtures of the {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2}.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} sat at the same kitchen table in the {Meadowlane Quarter|LOCATION-3} where previous plans had been drawn up and carefully erased goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}’s name from the penciled starting five before writing “{Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} (GK)” in neat block letters beside the opening league fixture.

Next to the updated goalkeeper line in the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} notebook, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} added a short reminder note to simplify early build-out patterns and to emphasize extra communication drills with student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} in the coming week.

On the afternoon of 2025-08-23, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} telephoned student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} to confirm that {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} would start in goal for {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} in the opening {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} match while goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} followed medical rest guidelines.

The call to student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} came shortly after 14:00, with student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} answering from a bedroom desk where school notebooks and a small bag containing goalkeeper gloves were laid out from a recent physical education session.

During the conversation, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} told student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} that the first {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} fixture was scheduled for late August and asked student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} to arrive 20 minutes early to the next team training to run through basic communication and restart routines.

Later on 2025-08-23, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} spoke directly by phone with goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} to explain that {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} would use goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} in goal and that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} could be eased back as a limited-minutes outfield substitute in early {Selvarin Inter-District Schools Futsal League|EVENT-2} games if doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26}’s conditions were met.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} began the call by reinforcing to goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} that the absence of any fracture on the {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} x‑ray was positive news, before outlining that the temporary role change was being made strictly in line with orthopedic physician doctor {Sevin Karlo|PERSON-26}’s recommendations.

Coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} told goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} that, once light jogging and passing felt comfortable without sharp pain, {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} might use goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} for short, low‑contact shifts as a defender or pivot with clear instructions to avoid sliding challenges and any falls onto the right wrist.

In the early evening of 2025-08-23, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} posted a summary message in the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group informing the {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} squad that {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} would start in goal and that goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16} would follow a gradual return plan based on {Meadowlane Crossway Clinic|ORGANIZATION-12} guidance before resuming full goalkeeping.

Around 18:45, coach {Harven Soll|PERSON-13} typed a three‑paragraph update into the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group that briefly described the moderate sprain diagnosis, thanked the squad for their earlier support of goalkeeper {Riven Hall|PERSON-16}, and asked the players to give student goalkeeper {Jasmin Korrel|PERSON-25} full backing in training and matches.

Within minutes of the message, several players from {Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17|ORGANIZATION-4} replied in the {Meadowlane U17 Futsal Chat|ORGANIZATION-11} group with short responses such as “we’re with you both” and “let’s be ready for the league,” indicating quick acceptance of the adjusted goalkeeping plan.

continuation.summary: On 2025-08-26, Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 and Varlen Crest Futsal Club Under-17 held a shorter joint video-review at Varlen Crest Training Hall using selected clips from their 2–1 rematch, but the coaches chose to focus on build-out mistakes rather than “Pressing in Pairs,” agreeing to open the school league with a slightly less aggressive press while they tidy their possession structure.

history.event_update: Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center hosted all of Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17's matches, including the 2–1 semifinal and 3–0 final on the main court, using its blue synthetic futsal surface and electronic scoreboards before a crowd of about 450 for the final.

building.material: steel-and-concrete frame with insulated panels

event.name: Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship
event.description: A regional youth futsal tournament that brings together under-17 teams from surrounding districts for structured competitive play each year.

history.event_update: The Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship concluded on 2025-03-22 at Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center, with Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 winning the title after a 3–0 final victory over Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17.

miscellaneous.name: selvars
miscellaneous.description: Selvars are the official fiat currency of Kerevalia, used for everyday consumer transactions and regional trade.

history.event_update: Selvars were the currency unit used for the championship budget and for the 3,000-selvar development grant awarded to Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17.

miscellaneous.name: Group A
miscellaneous.description: Group A is a standard pool-based classification label commonly used to organize teams into the first preliminary group in round-robin tournaments.

history.event_update: Group A was the preliminary pool in which Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 topped the standings with three wins from three matches during the championship.

person.name: Laren Vos
person.description: A technically gifted and fiercely competitive teenager who channels his energy into structured training and careful self-improvement.

history.event_update: During the championship, Laren Vos scored Selvarin East Secondary Under-17's lone goal against Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 in Group A via a 6-meter penalty.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal forward
person.education: upper secondary student (science track, in progress)

person.name: Ren Talvek
person.description: A calm and analytical young goalkeeper who thrives under pressure and approaches each match with meticulous preparation.

history.event_update: Ren Talvek helped backstop Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17's title run by conceding only two goals in five matches and earning player-of-the-match honors in two group-stage fixtures.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal goalkeeper
person.education: upper secondary student (sports-focused program, in progress)

person.name: Daren Mol
person.description: A quick and expressive wide player who enjoys the creativity of attacking play and values close friendships with teammates.

history.event_update: Daren Mol opened the scoring for Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 in their 2–1 semifinal victory over Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17 at the championship.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal winger
person.education: lower sixth-form student (general studies)

person.name: Jorin Kale
person.description: A physically strong and tactically aware teenager who relishes the responsibility of organizing play in both attack and defense.

history.event_update: Jorin Kale scored the decisive second goal for Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 in the semifinal, finishing a set-play corner routine to secure a 2–1 win.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal pivot
person.education: upper secondary student (business track, in progress)

person.name: Elvin Sarro
person.description: A detail-oriented official who is respected for clear communication, consistent decisions, and a commitment to educating young players about the rules.

history.event_update: Elvin Sarro officiated the high-tempo semifinal between Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 and Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17 at the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship.

person.profession: physical education teacher and certified futsal referee
person.education: bachelor's degree in physical education

person.name: Mikel Ardan
person.description: A creative and outspoken teenager who naturally takes on leadership roles and enjoys studying the strategic side of sport.

history.event_update: Mikel Ardan captained Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 in the final, scoring twice in a 3–0 win over Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17 to clinch the championship title.

Mikel Ardan appeared on the June 2025 cover of Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly lifting the championship trophy, and later took part in the academy’s classroom review of the feature series that highlighted his team’s off-the-ball work.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal playmaker
person.education: upper secondary student (humanities track, in progress)

person.name: Sera Noll
person.description: A determined and hard-working young athlete who balances fast-paced sport with a strong interest in future medical studies.

history.event_update: Sera Noll added the third goal on a late fast break in the final, helping Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 secure a 3–0 victory and the tournament championship.

person.profession: secondary school student and youth futsal flank player
person.education: upper secondary student (science track, in progress)

person.name: Marlen Tiravo
person.description: A methodical and patient coach who emphasizes discipline, collective responsibility, and long-term development over short-term results.

history.event_update: Head coach Marlen Tiravo led Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 to the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship title and received the official development-grant confirmation letter from council representatives after the final.

Head coach Marlen Tiravo participated in extended tactical and cultural interviews for the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly feature series, was prominently quoted in the “Pressing in Pairs” article, and led a classroom-style review session using the published diagrams with his under-17 squad on 2025-06-30.

person.profession: youth futsal coach and physical education instructor
person.education: master's degree in coaching and sports pedagogy

person.name: Lina Veress
person.description: An observant and articulate communicator who enjoys crafting human-interest stories that highlight the dedication of young athletes and volunteers.

history.event_update: Lina Veress conducted the post-final courtside interview with head coach Marlen Tiravo on behalf of the Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council media team.

Lina Veress was commissioned by Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly to produce a multi-part analytical feature series on Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s title run, conducted in-depth interviews with head coach Marlen Tiravo, authored the “Pressing in Pairs” article, and had her work adopted by local coaches as a practical reference.

person.profession: sports communications officer and freelance journalist
person.education: bachelor's degree in media and communications

person.name: Ralen Ko
person.description: A meticulous and quietly driven editor who enjoys shaping long-form stories that amplify young people's experiences in sport.

history.event_update: As editor of Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly, Ralen Ko commissioned the three-part feature on Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17, coordinated permissions for using championship materials, and received positive informal feedback from local coaches after the issue’s 2025-06-30 release.

person.profession: magazine editor and youth sports writer
person.education: bachelor's degree in journalism

person.name: Doran Helv
person.description: A pragmatic administrator with a calm demeanor who is motivated by building clear structures and fair opportunities in community sport.

history.event_update: Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council chairperson Doran Helv authorized Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly’s use of official statistics and photographs from the championship through a two-page email agreement finalized on 2025-06-18.

person.profession: youth sports council chairperson
person.education: master's degree in sports administration

person.name: Hele Narm
person.description: A detail-focused visual designer who enjoys turning complex information into clean, approachable layouts for young readers.

history.event_update: Graphic designer Hele Narm transformed Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly’s match-analysis notes into full-page tactical diagrams and in-text sequences illustrating Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s pressing and transition patterns for the June 2025 issue.

person.profession: graphic designer and illustrator
person.education: bachelor's degree in graphic design

person.name: Harven Soll
person.description: An energetic schoolteacher and coach who values simple, well-organized training sessions and personal accountability from his players.

history.event_update: Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 coach Harven Soll used Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly’s June 2025 feature—especially drills from “Pressing in Pairs”—as reference material, marking them for inclusion in his July pre-season training plans.

person.profession: secondary school physical education teacher and futsal coach
person.education: bachelor's degree in physical education

person.name: Neris Dalvo
person.description: A policy-minded planner who focuses on making grassroots sport programs inclusive, sustainable, and grounded in clear developmental principles.

history.event_update: As development coordinator, Neris Dalvo contributed a “Council Perspective” note to the 2025-06-30 feature series, explaining the council’s focus on broad guidelines over team-specific case studies while praising Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s positive example.

person.profession: sports development coordinator
person.education: master's degree in education policy

organization.name: Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council
organization.description: A volunteer-led regional body that coordinates youth futsal leagues, referee development, and coach education programs.

history.event_update: The Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council organized and hosted the final day of the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship at Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center and awarded the champions a 3,000-selvar development grant.

The Orvath Ridge Schools Futsal Council granted Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly permission to use official statistics and photographs from the championship, supplied archival materials, and, through its development coordinator, clarified in the June 2025 issue that it would not produce separate case-study booklets on Grendale’s title run.

organization.mission_statement: To develop structured futsal opportunities for school-aged players while promoting fair play, safety, and inclusion.

organization.name: Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17
organization.description: An under-17 training squad that offers structured futsal development for talented adolescents from surrounding neighborhoods.

history.event_update: Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 represented the Grendale Suburban Zone, went unbeaten in five matches to win the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship, and received a 3,000-selvar development grant from the council.

Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 became the focus of a three-part analytical feature in Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly, with its training routines, tactical structures, and pressing patterns documented in depth and subsequently used by both its own players and external coaches as a reference point.

organization.mission_statement: To provide advanced futsal coaching and life-skills education for promising players in the under-17 age group.

organization.name: Grendale Youth Futsal Academy
organization.description: A community-based futsal academy providing age-tiered technical and tactical instruction for players from early childhood through late adolescence.

history.event_update: Grendale Youth Futsal Academy's under-17 squad, coached by long-time academy staff member Marlen Tiravo, captured the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship title.

Grendale Youth Futsal Academy hosted in-person interviews for the magazine feature at its office and a classroom review session on 2025-06-30, where the under-17 squad studied diagrams and passages from the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly series overlooking the academy’s indoor court.

organization.mission_statement: To make structured futsal training accessible to children and teenagers through affordable programs and community partnerships.

organization.name: Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17
organization.description: A school-based futsal program that fields an under-17 squad focused on participation, teamwork, and basic competitive experience.

history.event_update: Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17 competed in Group A of the championship, where they lost 3–0 to eventual winners Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17.

Meadowlane School Futsal Under-17’s program was indirectly influenced when its coach, Harven Soll, adopted drills and concepts from the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly “Pressing in Pairs” article into his July 2025 pre-season schedule.

organization.mission_statement: To encourage participation and teamwork among students through regular futsal training and inter-school competition.

organization.name: Selvarin East Secondary Under-17
organization.description: An academically oriented secondary school's under-17 futsal team that emphasizes discipline and balanced development on and off the court.

history.event_update: Selvarin East Secondary Under-17 took part in Group A, with forward Laren Vos scoring a 6-meter penalty in their narrow 2–1 defeat to Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17.

organization.mission_statement: To support students who wish to combine academic progress with structured futsal training at the under-17 level.

organization.name: Orvath Ridge Collegiate Under-17
organization.description: A collegiate preparatory school's under-17 futsal squad known for its emphasis on tactical understanding and fitness.

history.event_update: Orvath Ridge Collegiate Under-17 played in Group A of the championship, losing 1–0 to Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 during the group stage.

organization.mission_statement: To prepare motivated student-athletes for higher-level study and competition through disciplined futsal training.

organization.name: Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17
organization.description: A privately run training center's under-17 futsal squad that draws players from multiple schools along the riverfront districts.

history.event_update: Selvarin Riverside Training Center Under-17 reached the semifinals of the championship but were eliminated 2–1 by Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 after briefly leveling the score early in the second half.

organization.mission_statement: To deliver high-intensity futsal development programs for teenagers drawn from diverse school backgrounds.

organization.name: Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17
organization.description: A specialized sports school's under-17 futsal team that integrates intensive athletic training with standard academic studies.

history.event_update: Selvarin Central Sports School Under-17 advanced to the final at Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center, where they were defeated 3–0 by Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17.

organization.mission_statement: To integrate specialized athletic coaching with formal education for talented young players.

organization.name: Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly
organization.description: A small regional print and digital magazine that specializes in grassroots youth sport coverage, coaching education, and local athlete profiles.

history.event_update: Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly commissioned, produced, and on 2025-06-30 released a mid-year issue featuring Lina Veress’s multi-part analysis of Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s championship campaign, distributing about 2,500 copies across Selvarin City and the Grendale Suburban Zone.

organization.mission_statement: To provide accessible, practical coverage of youth sport that supports coaches, young athletes, and families in their local communities.

location.name: Grendale Suburban Zone
location.description: A predominantly residential commuter region on the western fringe of a metropolitan area, characterized by low-rise housing estates, small shopping strips, and neighborhood parks.

history.event_update: Grendale Suburban Zone was represented at the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship by its qualifying team, Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17, which went on to win the title.

Grendale Suburban Zone was indirectly involved when the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly issue featuring Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17 was distributed across the region and local coaches began informally using the series as a shared reference for training discussions.

location.name: Selvarin City
location.description: A mid-sized inland industrial and university city known for its manufacturing base, technical institutes, and active grassroots sports scene.

history.event_update: Selvarin City served as the host city for the Orvath Ridge Under-17 Futsal Championship, with matches held at Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center and drawing local school teams and spectators.

Selvarin City hosted the Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly editorial work, printing, and wide distribution of the June 2025 issue, and it was where several school futsal coaches adopted the magazine’s Grendale feature series as practical planning material.

art.name: Pressing in Pairs
art.description: An instructional sports-coaching article that breaks down a specific defensive concept into progressive training activities for developing youth players.

history.event_update: The article “Pressing in Pairs” was published in Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly’s 2025-06-30 issue, presenting Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17’s paired pressing pattern through progressive training blocks that local coaches began integrating into their own sessions.

art.creator: Lina Veress

art.name: Council Perspective
art.description: A concise opinion piece that outlines key priorities and limitations in grassroots sports development from an administrative point of view.

history.event_update: The editorial note “Council Perspective” appeared in the 2025-06-30 Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly issue alongside the Grendale feature series, outlining the council’s priorities and constraints regarding official educational materials on the championship.

art.creator: Neris Dalvo

Selvarin Orvath Indoor Center’s match footage from the championship was replayed by Selvarin Youth Sport Quarterly staff to extract tactical sequences that were converted into diagrams for the June 2025 feature on Grendale Youth Futsal Academy Under-17.
